data.title: Decoding Taylor Swiftâ€™s 'TTPD' Album: Lyric Parallels and Easter Eggs
data.meta_description: Taylor Swiftâ€™s 'The Tortured Poets Department' is filled with Easter eggs and references to her past songs
data.text:
Taylor Swift has fans (and Us Weekly staffers) busy with the release of 31 songs across two versions of her 11th studio album, The Tortured Poets Department.

Swift, 34, dropped TTPD on Friday, April 19, dropping the first 16 songs at midnight EST. Two hours later, she announced and released The Tortured Poets Department: The Anthology, featuring 15 additional tracks.

â€œIâ€™d written so much tortured poetry in the past 2 years and wanted to share it all with you.â€ she wrote in part via Instagram. â€œAnd now the story isnâ€™t mine anymoreâ€¦ itâ€™s all yours. ğŸ¤â€

On that note, keep reading for how Us breaks down all the theories that link The Tortured Poets Department songs to past Swift tracks and more:

â€˜Fortnight (feat. Post Malone)â€™

There are a few songs that Swift gave context to while debuting the album with iHeartRadio on Friday, and the lead single is one of them.

â€œFortnight is a song that I think really exhibits a lot of the common themes that run throughout this album. One of which being fatalism, longing, pining away, lost dreams. I think itâ€™s a very fatalistic album in that there are a lot of very dramatic lines about, you know, life or death,â€ Swift explained. â€œâ€˜I love you, itâ€™s ruining my lifeâ€™ â€” these are very hyperbolic, dramatic things to say. But itâ€™s that kind of album. Itâ€™s about a dramatic, artist, tragic kind of take on love and loss. â€˜Fortnightâ€™ â€” Iâ€™ve always imagined it took place in this American town where the American dream you thought would happen to you didnâ€™t, right? You ended up not with the person that you loved and now you just have to live with that every day, wondering what would have been, maybe just seeing them out and thatâ€™s a very tragic concept, really. So I was just writing from that perspective.â€

There is a telling parallel between the opening track and Midnightsâ€™ â€œHits Different,â€ which is also about the very dramatic fallout of a breakup.

â€œIs it you? Or have they come to take me away? / To take me away,â€ she sings in the 2022 song. In â€œFortnight,â€ Swift says, â€œI was supposed to be sent away / But they forgot to come and get me.â€

â€˜The Tortured Poets Departmentâ€™

The title track is full of references to famous musicians and poets, including an unhinged mention of Charlie Puth that fuels theories that the song is one of the many about Swiftâ€™s ex Matty Healy. The 1975 frontman once praised Puth via X. The nod to typewriters, tattoos and chocolate â€” itâ€™s The 1975 song â€œChocolate,â€ cannabis chocolate or just a previouslyunknown love for Hershey bars â€” also links the track to Healy.

â€œYou smokĞµd, then ate seven bars of chocolate / We declared Charlie Puth should be a bigger artist,â€ she sings. â€œI scratch your head, you fall asleep / Like a tattooed golden retriever.â€

Some fans have pointed out that the structure of the chorus matches up to the Fearless song â€œWhite Horse.â€ In â€œTTPD,â€ she sings, â€œI laughed in your face and said / â€˜Youâ€™re not Dylan Thomas, Iâ€™m not Patti Smith / This ainâ€™t the Chelsea Hotel, weâ€™rĞµ modern idiotsâ€™ and in â€œWhite Horse,â€ she declares, â€œThis ainâ€™t Hollywood / this is a small town I was a dreamer before you went and let me down / Now itâ€™s too late for you and your white horse.â€

Instead of a princess trying to find her prince, Swift is a bohemian poet trying to break free from her toxic, moody ex.

â€˜My Boy Only Breaks His Favorite Toysâ€™

â€œâ€˜My Boy Only Breaks His Favorite Toys is a song I wrote alone and itâ€™s a metaphor from the perspective of a childâ€™s toy being somebodyâ€™s favorite toy until they break you and then donâ€™t want to play with you anymore,â€ Swift explained on iHeartRadio. â€œWhich is how a lot of us our in relationships were we are so valued by a person in the beginning and then all of the sudden they break us or they devalue us in their mind and weâ€™re still clinging on to, â€˜No, no, no you shouldâ€™ve seen them the first time they looked at me.â€™ â€¦ Itâ€™s kind of a song about denial, really, so you can live in this world where thereâ€™s still hope for this broken, toxic relationship.â€

The song brings Us back to Swiftâ€™s â€œHits Differentâ€ as the Midnights song and â€œâ€˜My Boy Only Breaks His Favorite Toysâ€ both mention Barbieâ€™s man, Ken. â€œI used to switch out these Kens, Iâ€™d just ghost,â€ she sings in â€œHits Different.â€ In the new song, she states, â€œI felt more when we played pretend / Than with all the Kens.â€

â€˜Down Badâ€™

Swift has a wild explanation for another track fans believe to be penned about Healy: â€œThe metaphor in â€˜Down Badâ€™ is that I was comparing the idea of being love bombed where someone was like, you know, rocks your world and dazzles you and then just kind of abandons you as an alien abduction where you were abducted by aliens â€” this girl was abducted by aliens â€“ but she wanted to stay with them and then when they like drop her off in her hometown, sheâ€™s like, â€˜No, where are you going? I liked it there. It was weird but it was cool. Come back.â€™â€

The lyric â€œHow dare you think itâ€™s romantic leaving me safe and strandedâ€ has fans shook with the parallel to a line in 1989 bonus track â€œNew Romanticsâ€ from a decade prior: â€œPlease leave me stranded, itâ€™s so romantic.â€

â€˜So Long, Londonâ€™

Swiftâ€™s former partner Joe Alwyn enters the chat with â€œSo Long, Londonâ€ and track five links to several other songs said to be about the British actor, who she dated for nearly six years, most notably â€œYouâ€™re Losing Me.â€

â€œI canâ€™t find a pulse, my heart wonâ€™t start anymore / For you cause youâ€™re losing me,â€ Swift sings in the Midnights bonus track, written in 2021 and released in 2022. In â€œSo Long, London,â€ sheâ€™s officially done, singing, â€œI stopped CPR after all, itâ€™s no use.â€

At another point in the 2024 song, Swift sings, â€œ And Iâ€™m just getting the color back in my face / Iâ€™m just mad as hell â€˜cause I loved this place.â€ In â€œYouâ€™re Losing Me,â€ Swift noted that her â€œface was gray, but you wouldnâ€™t admit that we were sick.â€ (Itâ€™s also not a surprise Swift is â€œmad as hellâ€ that Alwyn ruined the U.K. for her as she once wrote a song about how much she loves the place in Loverâ€™s â€œLondon Boy.â€)

Another song on Midnights: 3am Edition titled â€œGlitchâ€ gets an update on TTPD. â€œFive seconds later, Iâ€™m fastening myself with a stitch,â€ she sings in the 2022 song. In 2024, Swift declares, â€œStitch undone.â€

â€˜But Daddy I Love Himâ€™

Swift fires back at critics of her relationship with controversial Healy in this track, which could be argued is a new version of 2008â€™s â€œLove Story,â€ also about two star-crossed lovers who donâ€™t have the support of their inner circle around them.

â€˜â€œStay away from her,â€™ the saboteurs / Protested too much / Lord knows the words we never heard / Just screeching tires of true love,â€ the pre-chorus in â€œBut Daddy I Love Himâ€ read. In the chorus, she continues: â€œAnd now Iâ€™m runninâ€™ with my dress unbuttoned / Screaminâ€™, â€˜But Daddy, I love him.â€™â€

In Love Story, she sings, â€œThat you were Romeo, you were throwing pebbles / And my daddy said, â€œStay away from Julietâ€ / And I was crying on the staircase / Begging you, â€œPlease donâ€™t go.â€™â€

Even before the song was out, fans were linking the track to The Little Mermaid as Ariel pleads to her dad to understand about her desire to be a human and live with Prince Eric.

â€˜Fresh Out the Slammerâ€™

Fans are torn over whether â€˜Fresh Out the Slammerâ€™ is about Healy or Alwyn, but there is a devastating link between lyrics about rings that make Alwyn more likely. After declaring in 2019 that sheâ€™d marry him with Loverâ€™s â€œpaper rings,â€ Swift is now singing about â€œimaginary ringsâ€ in â€œâ€˜Fresh Out the Slammer.â€

â€˜Florida!!! (feat. Florence + The Machine)â€™

While Swifties have been trying to link this song and the fact that Tampa, Florida was the first concert stop for Swift after her and Alwynâ€™s split was announced in April 2023, she explained that her interest in the state has more to do with the â€œFlorida manâ€ concept.

â€œI think I was coming up with this idea of, â€˜What happens if your life doesnâ€™t fit or your choices youâ€™ve made catch up to you and youâ€™re surrounded by these harsh consequences and judgment and circumstances did not lead you to where you thought you would be and you just want to escape from everything youâ€™ve ever known â€“ is there a place you can go?â€ she said. â€œI always watch Dateline and people, you know, have these crimes that they commit and they immediately escape town (and) go to Florida, try to reinvent themselves and have this new identity, blend in. And I think when you go through heartbreak, thereâ€™s part of you that thinks, â€˜I want a new name, I want a new life. I donâ€™t want anyone to know where Iâ€™ve been or know me at all.â€™â€

In â€œFlorida!!!,â€ Swift sings, â€œLittle did you know your homeâ€™s really only / A town youâ€™re just a guest in,â€ which is a far cry from her declaration in â€œLondon Boyâ€ (again, about Alwyn): â€œHome is where the heart is / You know I love a London boy.â€

Swift also pulls from Reputationâ€™s â€œDonâ€™t Blame Meâ€ with the drug metaphors. â€œLord, save me, my drug is my baby / Iâ€™ll be usinâ€™ for the rest of my life,â€ she first sang in 2017. In 2024, Swift calls Florida â€œone hell of a drug,â€ asking the sunshine state to â€œcome fâ€“k me up.â€

â€˜Guilty as Sin?â€™

Swift sings about emotional affairs in â€˜Guilty as Sin?,â€ which begins with a nod to one of Healyâ€™s bandâ€™s songs â€œThe Downtown Lights.â€ Swiftâ€™s song seems to have parallels to Loverâ€™s â€œFalse Godâ€ with more religious imagery. â€œWhat if I roll the stone away? / Theyâ€™re gonna crucify me anyway / What if the way you hold me is actually whatâ€™s holy?â€ she sings. â€œIf long-suffering propriety is what they want from me / They donâ€™t know how youâ€™ve haunted me so stunningly / I choose you and me religiously.â€

She also mentions the â€œvault,â€ which Swifites associate with bonus tracks on her rereleases and uses the term â€œguilty as sinâ€ in the song Carolina, released in 2022 for the movie Where the Crawdads Sing. â€œOh, Carolina knows / Why for years theyâ€™ve said / That I was guilty as sin / And sleep in a liarâ€™s bed,â€ she sings.

â€˜Whoâ€™s Afraid of Little Old Me?â€™

Swift takes on critics in this track, which is reminiscent of Folkloreâ€™s â€œMad Woman.â€

â€œYou caged me and then you called me crazy / I am what I am â€™cause you trained me / So whoâ€™s afraid of me?â€ she sings in the new song. In the 2020 song, she asked another question, â€œEvery time you call me crazy / I get more crazy / What about that?â€

â€˜I Can Fix Him (No Really I Can)â€™

A decade after Swift said in 1989â€²s â€œBlank Spaceâ€ that she can â€œmake the bad guys good for a weekend,â€ she returned to the concept on TTPD in another track deemed to be about Healy.

â€œThey shake their heads sayinâ€™, â€˜God, help herâ€™ / When I tell â€™em heâ€™s my man / But your good Lord doesnâ€™t need to lift a finger / I can fix him, no, really, I can / And only I can,â€ she sings.

â€˜lomlâ€™

This song has nearly as many callbacks as â€œSo Long, London.â€ In addition to sounding like a reminding fans of the grownup version of â€œWhite Horseâ€ musically, Swift appears to take a direct shot at one of her love songs about Alwyn. In Folkloreâ€˜s â€œPeaceâ€ (2020), she sings, â€œYou paint drehttps://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/taylor-swift-hints-at-buying-a-london-house-with-joe-alwyn-on-ttpd/amscapes on the wallâ€ and in â€œloml,â€ she declares, â€œWhen your impressionist paintings of heaven turned out to be fakes.â€

The lyric â€œI thought I was better safe than starry-eyed / I felt a glow like this, never before and never sinceâ€ also triggers callbacks to several songs with â€œglowâ€ imagery, including Evermoreâ€™s â€œIvyâ€ â€” â€œYour touch brought forth an incandescent glowâ€ â€“ and Loverâ€™s â€œThis Loveâ€ â€” â€œThis love is glowing in the dark.â€

â€˜I Can Do It With a Broken Heartâ€™

Swift reflects on the success of her Eras Tour coming at the same time as her split from Alwyn in this track, which reminds Us of Midnightâ€™s â€œYouâ€™re On Your Own Kid.â€

â€œâ€™Cause Iâ€™m a real tough kid / I can handle my sâ€“t / They said, â€˜Babe, you gotta fake it â€™til you make itâ€™ and I did,â€ she sings. â€œLights, camera, bitch, smile.â€ In â€œYOYOK,â€ she sings, â€œYouâ€™re on your own, kid / You always have been.â€

â€˜The Smallest Man Who Ever Livedâ€™

Another one that appears to have direct references to Healy, Swift sings that â€œit wasnâ€™t sexy once it wasnâ€™t forbidden,â€ Swift has written about cheating before in songs like â€œIllicit Affairsâ€ and tackled forbidden romances for other reasons (like family or fame backlash) in the aforementioned â€œBut Daddy I Love Himâ€ and â€œLove Story.â€

â€œAnd in plain sight you hid / But you are what you did / And Iâ€™ll forget you, but Iâ€™ll never forgive / The smallest man who ever lived,â€ she concludes the song. The forget and not forgive line takes Us back to the Eras Tour when fans scream Kendrick Lamarâ€™s â€œBad Bloodâ€ line, â€œYou forgive, you forget, but you never let it go,â€ to her each night.

â€˜The Alchemyâ€™

The first song on the album (and maybe ever) seemingly about Swiftâ€™s current boyfriend, Travis Kelce, is full of football references. She also uses similar language to a song she penned about Alwyn called â€œCall it What You Want.â€

â€œI brought a knife to a gunfight / They took the crown, but itâ€™s alright,â€ she sings at the top of the Reputation song. She later adds, â€œAll the drama queens taking swings / All the jokers dressinâ€™ up as kings.â€

In â€œThe Alchemy,â€ Swift returns to the circus and royal imagery: â€œSo when I touch down / Call the amateurs and cut â€™em from the team / Ditch the clowns, get the crown.â€

â€˜Clara Bowâ€™

Us did a full breakdown of Swiftâ€™s similarities to the OG â€œit girlâ€ from the Silent Screen era before this track was even released. What stands out post-listen is the parallels between Redâ€™s â€œNothing New,â€ in which she sings about the fears that her music would become irrelevant if her fans moved on. (Bow, for her part, had to make the tough transition from silent films to talkies.)

â€œThe crown is stained, but youâ€™re the real queen / Flesh and blood amongst war machines / Youâ€™re the new God weâ€™re worshipping / Promise to be dazzling,â€ she sings in â€œClara Bowâ€ (possibly making a reference to her drama with Big Machine Records.) Swift also continues to be self-deprecating (something she did a lot of Midnights) at the end of the track: â€œYou look like Taylor Swift / In this light, weâ€™re lovinâ€™ it / Youâ€™ve got edge, she never did / The futureâ€™s bright, dazzling.â€

â€˜The Black Dogâ€™

Itâ€™s likely Swift is singing about Alwyn with signs that the reference to â€œsome bar called The Black Dogâ€ pointing to a real pub in England. The lyric, â€œSix weeks of breaking clean air / I still miss the smoke,â€ immediately brought Us to â€œDaylightâ€ off of Lover. â€œClearing the air, I breathed in the smoke,â€ she sings on the 2019 song. Thereâ€™s also some remedies of 1989â€™s â€œClean,â€ in which she sings: â€œRain came pouring down / When I was drowning, thatâ€™s when I could finally breathe / And by morning Gone was any trace of you, I think I am finally clean.â€

â€˜Imgonnagetyoubackâ€™

Instead of drawing parallels to her own music on this one, fans think Swiftâ€™s lyrics pull from a 1975 song called â€œFallingforyou.â€ In addition to the (odd) similar styling, Swift sings, â€œWhether Iâ€™m gonna be your wife or / Gonna smash up your bike, I havenâ€™t decided yet,â€ while Healy croons: â€œAll we needâ€™s my bike and your enormous house.â€ (There is additional speculation that Swiftâ€™s Aston Martin reference in the song â€”â€œIâ€™m an Aston Martin that you steered straight into the ditch / Then ran and hidâ€ â€” is a nod to her rumored romance with F1 driver Fernando Alonso in spring 2023.)

â€˜The Albatrossâ€™

â€œThe Albatrossâ€ feels like it could be straight off Swiftâ€™s 2020 album Evermore. â€œCross your thoughtless heart / Only liquor anoints you / Sheâ€™s the albatross / She is here to destroy you,â€ she sings, before making a reference to the devil, which sheâ€™s previously done on several songs, including â€œCruel Summerâ€ off of Lover and â€œPeaceâ€ and â€œInvisible Stringâ€ off Folklore. â€œDevils that you know / Raise worse hell than a stranger / Sheâ€™s the death you chose / Youâ€™re in terrible danger.â€

â€˜Chloe or Sam or Sophia or Marcusâ€™

Fans are struggling to figure out if any of these names present real people. All signs point to no, but Swiftâ€™s fictional love triangle across three Folklore songs did end up serving as a way to learn the name of one of Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds with the reveal of Betty back in 2020. There is a parallel lyric between â€œSo if I sell my apartment / And you have some kids with an internet starlet / Will that make your memory fade from this scarlet maroon?â€ from the 2024 song to Midnightâ€™s â€œMaroon,â€ in which she sings, â€œThe rust that grew bĞµtween telephones / The lips I used to call home / So scarlet, it was maroon.â€

â€˜How Did It End?â€™

At track 21, Swift isnâ€™t done, but asking the question about the end of relationship. Swift compares romance to a game â€” â€œLost the game of chance, what are the chances?â€ she sings in â€œHow Did It End?â€ â€” which could be a line to â€œState of Graceâ€ off Red: â€œLove is a ruthless game / Unless you play it good and right.â€

â€˜So High Schoolâ€™

Swift is pretty clearly singing about Kelce again on this track â€” â€œYou know how to ball, I know Aristotleâ€ says it all. From the song, we learned the tight end is a fan of the American Pie movies and the video game Grand Theft Auto. While not a callback to another song, she also references a video of Kelce playing â€œMarry, Kiss or Killâ€ with her, Ariana Grande and Katy Perry back in 2016. (He opted to â€œkissâ€ her, for the record.) The song is complete with what fans think is a nod to their origin story of Kelce seeking her out via a friendship bracelet at a concert. â€œYou knew what you wanted and, boy, you got her,â€ she sings.

â€˜I Hate It Hereâ€™

Swift drops the most poetry references in this song, with fans tying the song to her Folklore bonus track â€œThe Lakes.â€

â€œIâ€™m lonely, but Iâ€™m good / Iâ€™m bitter, but I swear Iâ€™m fine / Iâ€™ll save all my romanticism for my inner life and Iâ€™ll get lost on purpose,â€ she sings on â€œI Hate It Here.â€ On â€œThe Lakes,â€ which is also about escaping, she includes a nod to English Romantic poet William Wordsworth via the line: â€œIâ€™ve come too far to watch some name-dropping sleaze tell me what are my words worth.â€

â€˜thanK you alMeeâ€™

The KIM of it all made this track one of the most-talked about following the double album drop. Us has plenty of deep dives into Swift vs. Kim Kardashian (and Kanye West) here and here. This diss track sort of serves as an older (and slightly more aggressive) version of Swiftâ€™s song â€œMean.â€ From â€œAll you are is meanâ€ in 2010 to â€œFâ€“k you, Aimeeâ€ in 2024, Swift has never been afraid to take on her bullies in song form.

â€˜I Look in Peopleâ€™s Windowsâ€™

On the 10th or so listen, â€œâ€˜I Look in Peopleâ€™s Windowsâ€ starts to sound a bit like â€œDeath By a Thousandâ€ Cuts on Lover. â€œI look in peopleâ€™s windows / Transfixed by rose golden glows / They have their friends over to drink nice wine,â€ she sings. The tempo is similar to, â€œI dress to kill my time, I take the long way home / I ask the traffic lights if itâ€™ll be alright / They say, â€˜I donâ€™t know.â€™â€

â€˜The Prophecyâ€™

Swift makes another biblical mention in this track â€” singing â€œI got cursed like Eve got bittenâ€ â€” and a reference to dreams, something Swift has done for years in songs like â€œWildest Dreams,â€ â€œPaper Ringsâ€ and â€œâ€¦Ready for It?â€

â€œCards on thĞµ table / Mine play out like fools in a fablĞµ / Oh, it was sinking in (Sinking in, oh) / Slow is the quicksand / Poison blood from the wound of the pricked hand / Oh, still I dream of him,â€ she sings on â€œThe Prophecy.â€

â€˜Cassandraâ€™

After the obvious shot at Kardashian a few songs prior, Swift may be taking on Kimye again in â€œCassandra,â€ but she also draws a parallel to Reputationâ€˜s â€œI Did Something Bad.â€ (The song could also be about Scooter Braun.)

â€œWhen itâ€™s â€˜Burn the bitchâ€™â€ theyâ€™re shrieking / When the truth comes out, itâ€™s quiet,â€ Swift sings in â€œCassandraâ€ years after declaring, â€œTheyâ€™re burning all the witches, even if you arenâ€™t oneâ€ in 2017. (Cassandra is also the witch-like soothsayer of Greco-Roman myth.)

â€˜Peterâ€™

Swift calls on the Peter Pan reference that she first made in Folkloreâ€™s â€œCardiganâ€ â€” â€œTried to change the ending, Peter losing Wendyâ€ â€” in the new song with a heartbreaking twist to signal the end of the relationship for good:. â€œForgive me Peter, please know I that I tried.â€ (Healy has also used the character to describe himself in the past.)

â€˜The Bolterâ€™

â€œThe Bolterâ€ gives â€œGetaway Carâ€ â€” and Us knows â€œnothing good starts in a getaway carâ€ as the Reputation track puts it.

â€œStarted with a kiss / â€˜Oh, we must stop meeting like thisâ€™ / But it always ends up with a town car speeding,â€ she sings in the 2024 track.

This might be a stretch, but hearing that the relationship in the song â€œended with the slam of a door,â€ offered a quick return to Swiftâ€™s debut album. â€œOur song is the slamming screen door / Sneakinâ€™ out late, tapping on your window,â€ she sings. Other fans suggest â€œThe Bolterâ€ serves as a companion to â€œItâ€™s Time to Goâ€ from Evermore.

â€˜Robinâ€™

Swift sings about childhood with animal imagery on â€œRobin.â€ The song may be a continuation of â€œNever Grow Upâ€ from 2010â€™s Speak Now, which is also about maintaining innocence. The lyrics â€œyou have no room for regretâ€ (â€œRobinâ€) and â€œyou got nothing to regretâ€ (â€œNever Grow Upâ€) fuel this theory. Swiftâ€™s collaborator Aaron Dessner has a son named Robin, which could serve as the inspiration for the track name.

â€˜The Manuscriptâ€™

The final song on the 31-track double album has been linked to Swiftâ€™s ex John Mayer due to the references on a large age gap â€” and dating boys â€œyour own ageâ€ after it didnâ€™t work out. The song is about reflecting on the romance and has lyric parallels to two other songs â€” â€œWouldâ€™ve, Couldâ€™ve, Shouldâ€™veâ€ and â€œThe Story of Usâ€ â€” that are rumored to be about Mayer whom Swift dated when she was 19 and he was 32.
